data.text: Best 700x45 Bicycle Tires for Rough Terrain?

Best 700x45 tires for touring over rough terrain? Rocky mountain roads and occasional loose dirt. I'll sacrifice comfort and affordability for a tire that is rugged and won't wear down as fast on pavement miles in between. TIA!
I like the wtb resolute. They say 42, but measure close to 45. Whatever you get, throw some cushcore sun the front and rear and reduce your psi 3-5.
data.author: Jason Holzworth

data.text: ran those for 2000+ with no punctures. Love em!
data.author: Josh Ivaska

data.text: they feel pretty supple too!
data.author: Jason Holzworth

data.text: If you want something quite tough, reliable and will last long...decently fast rolling, maybe the Hutchinson Touregs?
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: Im running maxxis ramblers and love them so far but have no idea how many miles I can get out of them.
data.author: Deanne Boyd

data.text: I have 2,000 miles on mine so far and they still look good.
data.author: Jeff Ivey

data.text: I just double checked my mileage. It’s 1,600, not 2,000.
data.author: Jeff Ivey

data.text: Still very good I really like them. I only have 180 on mine
data.author: Deanne Boyd

data.text: Resolute are nice. Check out Rene Herse options too
data.author: Bobby Ruple

data.text: the Rene Herse are great tires but really tough to keep seated.
data.author: Jerome Guerard

data.text: Pirelli cinturano
data.author: Toby Robertson

data.text: I really like the teravail cannonballs. Also the Kenda Flintridge pro
data.author: Robert Gawthrop

data.text: Love my Flintridge and E’plor combo.
data.author: Curtis Johnson

data.text: Continental Rode tour tires are your best bet. They may not look like the right choice but they are more of the right choice than anything that’s been mentioned. Just because a tire had knobs doesn’t mean it has better traction or lifespan. The Ride tour has plenty of traction and will last much longer than any knobby trie.
data.author: James Falke

data.text: I use Swalbe Marathon Plus tyres for my overseas cycling trips in Portugal and Spain. The roads are a mixture of dirt, large sharp gravel, sand, cobbles etc etc. I have never had a puncture yet. Most serious tourers use Swalbe Marathon Plus tyres as they are bomb proof. They are not the most comfortable ride as they are hard, but that is what you need over large sharp gravel.
data.author: Jim Hislop

data.text: Maxxis Rambler 700 x 45c TR SilkShield
data.author: Jeff Kerkove

data.text: The Pirelli Cinturato Gravel M have been solid for me. Not as supple as the WTB resolute they replaced, but seem to be wearing a little better after ~500 miles
data.author: Eric Healy

data.text: I'm running the H version and they're great too, a bit flatter on the center, so smoother on tarmac.
data.author: Tom Harlow

data.text: I might have to try them in the future. Right now my go-to fast gravel tire is the Pathfinder Pro, but I should try a few more competitors
data.author: Eric Healy

data.text: Great tyre
data.author: Stephen Stead

data.text: I use the maxxis 700x45 tires and love them
data.author: Ben Morgan

data.text: Hello Richard. I’ve been riding the Challenge Gravel Grinder for quite some time and it performs very well both in the dirt and asphalt. I use both the 700x42 and 700x38. I’ll send the tread pattern pic next.
data.author: Brent Schlangen

data.text: Tread pattern.
data.author: Brent Schlangen

data.text: WTB Resolute Thee Best
data.author: Ray Anthony Gagliardino

data.text: Maxxis Rambler's
data.author: Britt Batterton

data.text: Plus one for the Maxxis Ramblers
data.author: David R Pletcher

data.text: Maxxis Ramblers 700 x 45c on back, 700 x 50c on front. For desert southwest including Arizona and New Mexicos high countries. After trying about 5 different tires.
data.author: Grant Rowe

data.text: The Donnelly EMP 45’s are definitely worth a look at. I enjoy them on blacktop, chunky gravel and hard pack dirt. Check out the reviews and see if they are right for your conditions. Donnelly’s don’t get the ink that the bigger names do, but they’re worth a look.
data.author: Kevin Pedersen
